questions.question: A group of students participated in a competition to estimate the mass of a jar of marbles. The cumulative frequency diagram below shows the estimation by the students. (a) Use the graph to estimate (i) median, Answer .................................... g [1] (ii) interquartile range for the mass of the jar of marbles. Answer .................................... g [2]
(b) Estimate the number of students who answered that the mass of the jar of marbles is at least 500 g. Answer ....................................... [2]

(c) To increase the difficulty of the competition, the organiser announced that a jar with greater mass of marbles will be used next week. Describe how the cumulative frequency curve for the estimation by students next week will differ from the current competition. ................................................................................................................................................ ...........................................................................................................................................[1]

The table below shows the distance, in km, ran by each of the members of a club, in a week. Distance (km) Number of members 0 \leq x < 5 2 5 \leq x < 10 4 10 \leq x < 15 11 15 \leq x < 20 d 20 \leq x < 25 4 25 \leq x < 30 3 (a) (i) Complete the following cumulative frequency table for the data given. [1] Answer Distance (km) Number of members x < 5 2 x < 10 x < 15 x < 20 23 x < 25 x < 30
(b) Find an estimate of the (i) mean of the distance ran, Answer .................................km [1]
(ii) standard deviation of the distance ran. Answer .................................km [1]

A = \begin{pmatrix} 6 & 3.1 \\ 5 & 1 \end{pmatrix}, B = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 3 \\ 4 & 1.8 \end{pmatrix} \text{ and } C = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 3 \\ 5 & 4 \\ y & 6 \end{pmatrix}. (a) Evaluate A + B. Answer ....................................... [1]
(b) It is given that B = C, find the value of y. Answer ....................................... [1]

A dance school offers dance sessions for cultural and international dance students on weekdays and weekends. Each student has a 10-week block of lessons with one session per week. The matrix D shows the number of students attending the dance lessons each week in one 10-week block. \[ D = \begin{pmatrix} 10 & 5 \\ 8 & 3 \end{pmatrix} \] (a) Evaluate the matrix L = 10D.
(b) The dance school charges $80 for each cultural dance session and $90 for each international dance session. Represent the session charges in a \(2 \times 1\) column matrix C.
(c) Evaluate the matrix G = LC.
(d) State what the elements of G represent.

(e) The dance school wants to attract more students, so in the next 10-week block, the dance school reduces the price for cultural and international dance sessions by 10%. For this block of sessions, on weekdays, there are 5 cultural dance students and 12 international dance students. On weekends, there are 8 cultural dance students and 15 international dance students. By using matrix multiplication, calculate the total amount of money the dance school earns for this 10-week block of sessions.

Given that P is the point (1, 1), \( \overrightarrow{PQ} = \begin{pmatrix} 3 \\ -1 \end{pmatrix} \) and \( \overrightarrow{PR} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \), find (a) \( \overrightarrow{QR} \).
(b) the coordinates of the point X such that PQXR is a parallelogram.

In the diagram, ABCD is a parallelogram. Y is the midpoint of BD, X is the midpoint of BY and Z is the point on AB such that AB = 3AZ. (a) Given that \( \overrightarrow{AZ} = 2p \) and \( \overrightarrow{AD} = 2q \), express as simply as possible, in terms of p and/or q (i) \( \overrightarrow{BD} \).
(ii) \( \overrightarrow{ZY} \).
(iii) \( \overrightarrow{XC} \).
(b) Using your answers in (a)(ii) and (a)(iii), deduce two facts about XC and ZY.
